Award.AwardTitle: IUSE: EHR: Enabling field experiences in introductory geoscience classes through the use of virtual reality

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate the use of virtual reality technologies to create virtual field experiences for use in introductory geosciences classes. Although field experiences are an important aspect of geoscience education, there are few opportunities to provide physical world experiences to many undergraduate students due to access, logistical, and financial constraints. Thus, geoscience instructors must develop novel teaching and learning opportunities that closely approximate the information, elements, and environment students would find on a physical, in-person field study. The types of virtual experiences developed through this project, while different from their physical corollaries, will give learners the chance to engage with learning content and activities through multi-modal interactions in the virtual environment. The use of virtualization tools will create opportunities that give geoscience educators access to interactive, contextualized teaching materials, and learners access to a space for exploration and discovery. The development of virtual reality field experiences will also create a pathway for a diverse audience of students to encounter the earth sciences, particularly those from underrepresented groups, resource-limited institutions, and majors traditionally not directly involved in the earth sciences. Enhancing access to educational opportunities for these groups will aid in developing the engaged, diverse and earth-science literate population that is needed to address societal needs in a complex and changing world.

The project will develop a virtual reality field-trip of the Grand Canyon that will be accessible to a wide audience in diverse educational settings. Through the experience, students will develop core geoscience concepts as they find and evaluate evidence that will help them piece together the geologic history of the region. In the virtual experience, students will apply their knowledge of rock and mineral properties, build their understanding of spatial and temporal relationships between Earth processes, learn how these relationships are recorded in the rock, and ultimately synthesize their observations into a coherent geologic story that they will encapsulate in lay terms as a virtual brochure for the Canyon. The project will also develop a virtual reality toolbox for earth science educators that will facilitate the future development of additional virtual field activities. The project will utilize new innovations in the field of virtual reality, e.g., Oculus Rift technology, to provide geoscience educators the means to give every student a first-person virtual field experience. The virtual field experiences will be designed to emphasize key aspects of geoscience learning (i.e., temporal thinking, spatial thinking, earth systems, and field learning) and integrate the 'Big Ideas' in geoscience proposed by the Earth Science Literacy Initiative. The specific learning activities that will be developed in the project are strongly grounded in the existing geoscience education, STEM education, and game-based learning literature and will utilize built-in learning analytics for improved assessment of student learning. By addressing both the affective and cognitive routes to learning, this approach holds promise to increase student engagement and concept retention in the classroom.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A prototype for the Grand Canyon Virtual Reality Field Experience (VRFE) was created and tested with students.  The learning activity is a virtual reality experience designed to work on student smartphones using a low-cost set of VR lenses, such as Google Cardboard.  Overall learning goals for the experience are aligned with the content of an introductory physical geology course.  In the prototype students move through a virtual representation of the Grand Canyon to collect and test 3D models of rock samples, which were created from photogrammetric reconstruction of real samples.  Through their investigation, students build an understanding of the historical environments that led to the formation of the Canyon.  At the time this grant was awarded, there was very little prior literature available exploring how to create or utilize immersive VR for teaching in the geosciences.  As a result, we have made many advances in developing best practices for the creation of VR field trips.  For example, a substantial degree of effort has gone into evaluating the degree to which smartphones can support different representations of a geologic environment. These range from the use of photorealistic 360-degree imagery to cartoon representations of a field site (with lower-memory requirements), photogrammetric reconstructions of real-world environments, and 3D environments constructed from actual topographic data.  The project has also demonstrated methods for integrating game-like mechanics for interacting with the environment and the integration of narrative storytelling as a method for motivating the exploration of learning content.  The VRFE prototype was tested with 41 student participants from various STEM and non-STEM fields.  This evaluation showed that students greatly enjoyed the VR experience and reported learning from it.  The students also indicated that they would like the opportunity to experience more VR activities to learn about the world.  Somewhat surprisingly, we found that students found themselves to experience a strong sense of presence in the virtual world, even if this world was not realistic.  This finding suggests that realism is not as important as creating engaging environments to increase student interest in learning about the geosciences, though additional research is required to further investigate this issue across course levels and utilizing different technologies.  The student evaluations also showed that females and non-STEM students reported significantly higher learning outcomes and felt a greater sense of presence in the virtual environment.  These outcomes suggest that the use of virtual reality as a teaching tool in the geosciences may therefore aid in better engaging these groups. 

Intellectual Merit: The study developed a new approach for teaching geoscience content using virtual reality.  Evaluation outcomes have shown that this approach has positive learning outcomes that are likely to encourage increased interest in the geosciences. 

Broader Impacts:  The project represents one of the first efforts to utilize immersive virtual reality in geoscience education and has shown that highly effective experiences can be created for deployment on student mobile devices.  This outcome is important as it shows that VR can lower institutional and personal barriers to providing introductory geology students access to field trips, which are known to be an essential element to building student interest in the geosciences.
